title: Before 1 October 2021, will any group of Amazon employees in the U.S. vote in the affirmative to form a union?
preds: Employees in the U.S. will vote in the affirmative to form a union and Amazon will try in many ways to prevent this from happening. The pandemic has changed the retail landscape significantly and the group of individuals who are feeling the brunt of this change are the workers in the distribution hubs about the U.S. There has been reports of injuries, positive COVID outbreaks in distribution hubs, and a great deal of stress meeting high quotas set by Amazon. This coming holiday season will be extra stressful for these workers. Employees will vote to form a Union just so they can have the ability to have their serious concerns heard.

Baseline: no group of amazon employees is unionized in the USA and the company recently defeated a union vote in AL by a 2:1 margin. 
Adj to baseline: there is no news of an upcoming union vote on the horizon. Given that these take months to organize and canvas employees on both sides and that there is <2 weeks remaining in the month, I do not see any way this could happen.

Since there is no indication that a vote will take place (as far as I can tell) before the 1st of October, it seems extremely unlikely that a vote could be demanded, organised, and take place by then.
Time has run out on this one.
Uneducated work force will not vote for a union
Time is running out for this to be possible.

This most likely not happen by October 1st. It might be a second vote where warehouse worker will have the chance to vote again to for the Union but for this to happen it will be some legal barriers, therefore, it will take some time get organize the vote.

https://apnews.com/article/technology-business-c17604ab207b56f5b110a6ca63bb5f09
Maybe, but I'm pretty sure the various timetables don't allow this to happen before October.
Not changing my forecast, however, NLRB recommends the Bessemer result should be voided due to illegal interference by Amazon: https://t.co/5Sh9NgMVIO?amp=1
Updating as probability is no longer zero (https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2021/aug/02/amazon-warehouse-workers-union-second-vote)
Changing the probability from 10% to 1%, as Oct 1st is now 2 months away and there are no new significant news.

If it was a warehouse in Birmingham, UK, I would expect them to vote to form a union, because it gives them a collective voice and the strength to be able to negotiate with the management.  The US workers give the impression of having a forelock tugging relationship with their employers and appreciate the scraps that their company owners throw at them, so I can only suggest a 50/50 outcome.

There isn't enough chatter on the news. https://trends.google.com/trends/explore?geo=US&q=amazon%20union. 
There was a recent vote by the Teamsters union to push in this direction, but there isn't enough time till Oct 1 to organize and succeed at such a vote.
The Teamsters Union are getting involved but a vote in less than 3 months is unlikely.  https://www.wsj.com/articles/teamsters-union-votes-to-help-organize-amazon-workers-11624558332
I am not aware of any upcoming votes before this date.
Amazon is just going to pay more because he does not want Russian influence in the unions. Their HR needs to watch individuals trying to form unions. Gothcha hook line sinker.
Time is running out on this one.  Might not be enough time to organize and hold a vote before October.

Pre-election decision to schedule an election has to be 20 business days before the election: https://www.shrm.org/resourcesandtools/legal-and-compliance/employment-law/pages/nlrb-rule-more-time-before-union-elections.aspx so say the pre-election decision has to happen by Sep 1. Bessemer, Alabama workers filed with NLRB in *November.* NLRB open representation cases: https://www.nlrb.gov/reports/graphs-data/recent-filings?f%5B0%5D=case_type%3AR&s%5B0%5D=Open&s%5B1%5D=Open%20-%20Blocked only one I see mentioned is Bessemer, AL Alabama, Delaware voted against joining a union. Alabama by a 2:1 margin; Delaware by ~3:1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amazon_worker_organization Labor may prefer protests and walkouts over elections: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/09/business/economy/amazon-labor-unions.html

While Teamsters getting involved the timing is key. May not be able to happen with time left. https://www.shrm.org/resourcesandtools/legal-and-compliance/employment-law/pages/nlrb-rule-more-time-before-union-elections.aspx
Pretty sure the lead time to sort the paperwork for a sanctioned vote is now too short to hit this date.

Hard to see where it happens now after the defeat in Alabama. At least not before 10/1/2021.
https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/the-union-battle-at-amazon-is-far-from-over
This won't happen, at least by then.

There is increasing cause that the Alabama unionization vote might be overturned and another vote taken.  Also, keep an eye on Amazon facilities in Iowa.  Apparently, there is a small, but growing effort in that state.
It has the path build for it.
I'm simply unaware of - and can find no evidence of - any effort currently under consideration.
Takes quite a long time to get this process started, and even longer to get it finished.  This proposition is unlikely in any imminent time frame, but almost certainly infeasible by 1 October.
Watch the National Labor Relations Board meeting on the 7th.  It could result in a revote in Alabama.

The surprisingly overwhelming vote to not unionize in Alabama really hurts unions' efforts to unionize Amazon.  However, two factors must remain in consideration.  The unions are determined to crack open Amazon and will be persistent in trying elsewhere.  Additionally, the union is appealing the vote.  The other factor is the vote was in Alabama, not exactly the friendliest state to unions,  Such efforts could be successful in another state this year.
After the crushing defeat any and all attempts will be pushed by the wayside before a vote even takes place.

After Alabama vote I am downgrading my prediction. I still think there is a possibility at a subsidiary and the Bezos quote of "Union defeat doesn't bring me comfort" seems less anti-union. The vote may also push amazon to be more worker-friendly which would lower the chance of a vote in affirmation to form a union.  https://www.msn.com/en-us/money/companies/jeff-bezos-union-defeat-does-not-bring-comfort/ar-BB1fGNBd

An interesting article about the union movement changing its strategy following their sound defeat in Alabama.  It suggests they will move away from their previous focus on single location unionizing toward nationwide worker conditions.[1]  If this is their new direction, for the purposes of our question, this would make the chances of a "yes" by September 30 approach zero. In examining my initial overconfidence in my own view on this question, I see the union movement making the same error: mistaking that strong public rejection of inequality will overwhelm local attitudes that do not support unions.  National union leaders seem to think that they do not have to do the hard work of door knocking and shoe leather persuasion and can just ride the tide of history.  Similarly, certain Democratic strategists believe that demography destines their party to dominate the future, while neglecting specific individual races, causing them to lose ground badly in the House and state houses while continuing to win large majorities of the popular vote nationally. [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/09/business/economy/amazon-labor-unions.html
After the Alabama Amazon workers rejecting to join the union by a big margin, it is unlikely that a union will be formed within Amazon by 1 October.
Still a "no" this is a defensive "no" on my part, but I feel the crowd has overcorrected. Remember, steer *into* the skid...
So Alabama union lost and by a long way.  Reduces likelihood of other and will take some time to get to ballot.  Not aware of any other amazon sites at a ballot point yet.
I will dare to be more specific. It will be in the Midwest, if at all.

In my initial answer to this question I'd considered the possibility that the Alabama vote would prompt numerous other attempts at unionisation, but this hasn't happened. With less than 6 months left until the deadline the potential for other votes completing in time is diminishing.
This maybe should be 5%. I'm in the process of refining.
Well that did not go all that well, still not over but time is running out

Just a rough estimate probability, .27 chance another group holds another vote * .25 chance they win * .50 chance it meets time frame. Alternatively, the best case, worst case, and no change scenarios together favor unlikely chances. Keep an eye out on this one!

Even if another batch starts the process, it takes a long time to organize the voting process, then carry it out, then count the votes.  Not clear from the Q whether disputes and appeals must be resolved before the Q is scored.  However, even if everything goes smoothly--and it won't--the dance might well drag on past 1 October.
Thought the Bessemer, Alabama unionizing was the best chance. Don't see any other unionizing efforts on the horizon right now.

There is just time for another petition and to hold a vote, but after what looks like a bad loss for the union effort in Alabama organizers will probably want to build up a better base of support before trying this again.

Abrupt U-turn after having bought in to pro-union media propaganda.  Perhaps they chose the wrong place to pick a fight. But early leaks about voting patterns suggest the outcome will weaken further the the fabric of the labor movement and iconic go-to labor leaders like Trumka who make myths for the media that Big Labor is tough. If there was a brawl between  Joe Manchin and hIs friends and Trumka and his crew, I suspect Trumka woud wind up getting the "wood shampoo"....
I remember the cold blooded assasination of UMW boss Jock Yablonsky by a Kentucky gunman half a century ago. And the milquetoast behavior of englishman Lane Kirkland after George Meany checked out.  Sadly, the labor movement is living in a land of make believe.  No big time solidarity for the Bessemer workers from Teamsters, UMW.  The unions of pro athletes who do actually wield  power are too rich to care.  And it is not like there is no corruption in organized labor neither. The Bessemer vote has already cost Applebaum and his outfit beaucoup bucks.  Amazon will do whatever it takes to continue to create a tsunami of publicity and other fun stuff to quash efforts to organize eleswere in the US.  This coming from a third generation legacy of the AFL and AFL-CIO.  I helped pay my way though college working at Republic Steel and was a member of the United Steelworkers during the 60s.  I attended secondary school in Northen Ohio with members of the Presser family.  Look what's happened since...

Given the current political climate and economic unease globally, it's highly probably that Amazon employees will want to join a union. While many of their top-level employees are leading the charge, and would likely lean more left, a lot of their lower-level employees are in much more red states (i.e. Alabama), which is typically not a hot-bed of pro-union activity. That said, unionization would provide for high wages, better benefits, and more job security for those employees who need it most, so it is probable that they would vote in their own economic interests... especially if it's being pushed by high-ups within the organization for political purposes.

The Alabama vote will set the tone for anything else happening this year.

Down the interstate from Bessemer, Jim Spitzley has followed the Amazon vote with special interest. He works at a Mercedes-Benz plant — the epicenter of the last high-profile labor battle in Alabama. "It's going to be a big, big deal when (the Amazon election) happens," he says. "That's what it all comes down to, getting that vote ... and we haven't got that in 25 years on three attempts." https://www.npr.org/2021/01/28/960869795/for-amazon-and-alabama-warehouse-union-vote-would-shake-up-history

Nationally, a little less than 11% of American workers were represented by a union in 2020. Alabama was beneath that average, at 8%, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The number has fluctuated over the last few years. The union membership rate for the state was at its recent peak in 1993, when it averaged 14.7%, and at an ebb in 2017 at 7.4%. “Alabama was one of the most highly organized states in the union before right to work legislation,” Appelbaum said. “I think what’s really significant about this campaign too is that it’s as much of a civil rights struggle as a labor struggle.”
What happened to unions in Alabama in the later half of the 20th century reflected national trends. The influence of organized labor began to diminish with the decline of the industries - steel, coal and textiles. https://www.al.com/news/2021/02/alabamas-amazon-union-push-latest-chapter-in-states-tumultuous-labor-history.html#:~:text=Alabama%20saw%20widespread%20organizing%20in,both%20among%20Blacks%20and%20whites.

https://www.wired.com/story/amazon-historic-union-vote-gets-underway-alabama/ The election runs through March 29 and marks the first Amazon warehouse union vote since a group of technicians in Delaware voted against unionizing in 2014.

Bessemer is a "union town" its in Jefferson county most of the workers are from there or nearby counties that voted progressive in 2020, also had historically high voter turnout and high mail in ballot turn out in 2020, so they have recent familiarity with mail in elections, and support in the wider community. 
On the con side, Amazon has been actively opposing them and has a track record of successful opposing similar efforts in the past.  https://www.al.com/news/birmingham/2021/02/union-solidarity-rally-for-amazon-workers-braves-cold-rain.html

The fundamental question is whether 2,901 of these specific employees in Alabama making at least $15.30 an hour are motivated enough to mail in a ballot. My gut says no.
The NLRB sanctioned the vote by mail on 5 Feb for the Alabama warehouse workers.

Some key takeaways from a union worker/organizer's inside perspective:
"I hope they pull through, but I don’t think it is realistic. It’s 5,800 voters, with mail in ballot. Just that in itself is a very difficult challenge.  They need 50% plus 1 to win. Those ballots have to be in by a specific time and date no exemption’s. So you need 2,901 "yes" votes. Originally, they wanted a smaller unit of employees but it was ruled they had to include the full 5,800. Obviously, they also hired the best anti-union attorney’s in the country, with Trump NLRB Rules still in place, even though Biden fired the top 2 which was incredible. He can’t reverse the anti-union rules put in place the last four years. If they where able to keep the smaller unit the union would have a better chance." "So with Amazon in the metro areas construction Amazon has been great for union workers. When it comes to building their data centers, and distribution centers in the outer, rural areas they are about the worst it gets. Right now we putting together a campaign regarding their tax credits. ... They are building everything non-union and with out of state contractors who bring out of state workers. Not because they are non-union, but these contractors are horrible companies with records of killing people on the job from unsafe practices... exploiting works, it’s bad. A lot of the contractors they use come out of the mid-west/south. Or Utah. And they travel the U.S working exclusively on their projects. But it’s just not Amazon. Microsoft, Google, Yahoo! are all just as guilty as them." I asked him what he thought the odds were:
"Maybe 60% chance, I think you're going to see them lose. Then they will go after it again. Once you lose an election you can’t file for one year to vote again. By that time some NLRB Rules should change and fall in favor of organizing... Which most of us are banking on. " @nadie708 per your interest.

Voting by mail is scheduled to begin today. The question is whether the larger bargaining unit consisting of more than 5,000 employees will vote in the affirmative.  This election has been flagged for Biden as a huge deal with high stakes for organized labor. Anti union activities by Amazon have always beat the union. I'm betting against the odds this time as I think vote by mail as well as a supportive political environment will increase the turnout for the union.

Important to consult the law on this: If a majority of workers wants to form a union, they can select a union in one of two ways: If at least 30% of workers sign cards or a petition saying they want a union, the NLRB will conduct an election. If a majority of those who vote choose the union, the NLRB will certify the union as your representative for collective bargaining. An election is not the only way a union can become your representative. Your employer may voluntarily recognize a union based on evidence - typically signed union-authorization cards - that a majority of employees want it to represent them. Once a union has been certified or recognized, the employer is required to bargain over your terms and conditions of employment with your union representative. Special rules apply in the construction industry.
(https://www.nlrb.gov/about-nlrb/rights-we-protect/the-law/employees/your-right-to-form-a-union) In effect, a majority of those who vote have to be affirmative. We have 30%+ in the bag, as that is what triggered the election. The question therefore is "will more negative votes turnout that positive votes". Presumably it will be close, but getting the election seems to suggest that enough will tip it over the edge with postal voting.
No traction yet. Amazon has plenty of $ to increase wages, add benefits, and keep workers from Unionizing. It may happen but not by October 2021

I compared two articles regarding the Amazon unionization topic, NPR from January 15th (https://www.npr.org/2021/01/15/948819324/amazon-warehouse-workers-to-decide-whether-to-form-companys-first-u-s-union) and the Washington Post from February 2nd (https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/02/02/amazon-union-warehouse-workers/). Considering also that the public knowledge of poor working conditions for Amazon employees has been on the rise since the pandemic began, as well as the knowledge that Jeff Bezos is stepping down as Amazon CEO, I can see employees who are pro-union becoming more outspoken for higher wages and better working conditions. The more knowledge that comes out to the public about the tactics Amazon uses to discourage people from speaking out and unionizing as well makes me think that public outrage and maybe even a strike from Amazon workers is on the horizon if Amazon continues to push the limit on poor working conditions and silencing people. The most likely group from what it looks like so far is the Alabama Amazon warehouse.
An affirmative vote in Alabama has maybe a 65-70% chance but the long timeframe makes this one hard to avoid.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-amazon-com-labor/amazon-seeks-to-halt-union-election-at-alabama-warehouse-idUSKBN29R23P?utm_source=morning_brew

Details: As of Jan 23, plant of 6k in Bessemer is working to win right to vote to unionize. Amazon is fighting the vote, appealing to the US National Labor Relations Board.  COVID has provided Amazon an opportunity to challenge the method of the vote. Amazon has suggested the vote should be conducted in person rather than by mail because it argues that COVID infection rates are dropping in the county that the Bessemer Plant is located in. The vote is scheduled to begin on Feb 8 will all ballots due to be mailed in by Mar 29, and vote counted on Mar 30. This will be Amazon's first unionize vote since 2014. Source: The Verge, Jan 22.    Analysis: Given Biden's election and the pressure tech companies find themselves under, it is likely the NLRB will opt to move a vote forward, either by mail as planned or in person. A decision to vote in person may lead to delays, but a vote should occur before October 1 2021.
There is a possibility that a group of amazon employees will vote to unionize, but reported new taxes on Amazon by the new administration could inhibit these efforts.

I came across this article about Bessemer, Al.  https://www.bayoubrief.com/2020/03/01/bessemer-a-cautionary-tale/

The Bessemer warehouse opened just as Covid-19 arrived in the United States. Amazon announced plans for it in 2018, part of an expansion into midsize metropolitan areas so the company could store more products closer to customers for quick delivery. The local economy used to depend on steel industry jobs, but those have largely disappeared, and Amazon, which pledged to hire 1,500 people, received $51 million in local and state tax incentives. Average pay at the warehouse is $15.30 an hour, Ms. Knox said.
https://www.nytimes.com/2020/12/22/business/amazon-union-vote-bessemer-alabama.html
Incl Temp workers will make it harder to obtain majority especially given the high starting wage. And as has been pointed out before by @Econja2018 Alabama being an anti union state will just make things harder.

At this time the Bessemer vote will include any employee who has worked over four hours over the preceding 13 weeks. That accounts for around 6000 employees the site had an estimated workforce of 1500. This larger potential employee pool could help the unionists cause.

The Alabama vote to be held 8 Feb-29 March will be a first test. There is no clear indication of whether that particular group of workers is going to have a majority, given that only 30% were needed to call the vote. Given the timeframe and wording of the question, though, there is an increasing chance that "any group" will have some success with a worker-friendly administration/NLRB by 1 October.

According to the article "Amazon Workers Are Organizing a Global Struggle" (https://theintercept.com/2020/12/03/amazon-workers-union-international-strike/)  "Bezos could personally pay Amazon’s 876,000 workers a bonus of $105,000 each — and would still be as filthy rich as he was prior to the pandemic." The article also goes on to state that worker in the U.S. and UK were offered a $300 holiday bonus, all while being placed in close proximity in a holiday surge environment.  A change in U.S. administration will also heighten workers rights, and I assume may push local state leaders to support workers to challenge Amazon and support workers in an effort to unionize.
There will be no better time to do it (before the midterms), considering the pandemic, dem government, amazons wealth
As employees perceive their working conditions lessen and other tech companies joining unions it is inevitable that Amazon employees join the party.
With Democrats in full control of Congress and the Presidency, this gives them substantial room to expand support for union workers.
Clear benefits to unionisation, but Amazon have been very resistive to this globally

Looking for a base rate, unionization efforts appear infrequent and unsuccessful. The effort in Alabama look especially difficult as Amazon is a major employer offering job well above the local mean. The risk of shutting down the warehouse is significant to those voting on the effort. As it only takes 30% of the workforce to call for a vote, it isn't clear that there is majority support. There also don't appear to be strong motivating factors to organize around. While the workload is increasing, the pay is good and more secure than other retail outlets. I can't find any workforce injuries or fatalities in Bessemer that would bring closeness to a call for more worker protection. Therefore, the general population may be more upset with Amazon than the employee population is. While the incoming federal administration may offer more support to disgruntled workers, I don't think that factor is the predominant deciding point. It should come down to those people casting the votes weighing the risk of losing their jobs versus whatever upside unionization affords. During the pandemic, a $15 per hour job with a company that is expanding while watching friends and family laid off at other establishments should provide more gratitude than grief.  I would rate this much lower if not for the fact that "any" group of over a million employees seems like a broad stroke. An effort in Seattle, for example, would probably have a much higher chance of success. And, given the culture of Whole Foods, employees of those stores may be more likely to organize than others. If this question was strictly about the warehouse workers in Alabama, I would score it much lower. Still, getting a vote together is a long process and an uphill battle.

Amazon appears to have been successful in expanding the size of the bargaining unit from 1,500 to more than 5,700 (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-amazon-com-labor-yearend-focus/amazon-to-face-u-s-union-push-in-year-ahead-idUSKBN28X1BA).  Amazon has also managed to employ delaying tactics, and is still asking for an in-person vote rather than mail-in. I will start at 35% chance of a yes vote in the timeframe, the last vote in July 2014 being a clear no (https://www.vox.com/2014/1/15/11622392/amazon-warehouse-workers-vote-against-joining-union). On the basis that it the time for the Alabama group to actually vote has been 3 months so far, realistically it they fail the question would still allow other groups around 4-5 months to start the process, so if we assumed that one other group tries with the same success ratio as above the combined probability would be 58%. Given the baseline of only two votes since 1974, I will allocate a 15% chance of another group (higher than normal given the political environment - and the whole foods acquisition) organising a vote in time for the question, so starting with 38%.
It looks like the vote at Alabama warehouse is likely to happen before 1st Oct 2021.
I’ve seen this before...in South Park! But Colorado is different than Alabama.

I imagine it'll be a toss-up until we see what Google and Googlers do... Amazon deep pockets can certainly acquiesce to worker demands if need be, and professional union busters are unfortunately effective... but that might only come into play with warehouse workers.

The change in administration will change the NLRB, making it a much friendlier process for union organizers compared with the last four years. The new personnel at the DOJ will bring a renewed focus on antitrust.  Amazon’s strong arm tactics with unionization can only invite further scrutiny of all aspects of their business under a DOJ during a Democratic administration.  The pent up anger from folks who have not had the luxury to work from home during the pandemic and have been disproportionately effected by COVID will fuel public outrage if Amazon does not allow a vote for a union.  The annual news stories in Q3 on how little tax Bezos pays personally and Amazon pays as a corporation will further weaken their ability to fight workers organizing.  Bernie Sanders and Joe Biden agreed Sanders should not leave the Senate to become Labor Secretary, and I imagine this will give Bernie an outsized influence and ability to influence Biden and his administration.  All of these factors will constrain Amazon’s usual ruthlessness in crushing unionization, leading to my very high confidence level.
I believe Amazon will fight unionization as hard as Walmart has, and for essentially the same reasons. Both companies are relentlessly focused on efficiency, not employee welfare.

I'm only forecasting on this because it’s in the In The News 2020 challenge (although it launched in 2021) and I want to defend my leaderboard position.

Biden will be a great advocate for unionization.  I don't know how this Alabama election will turnout because the NLRB appears to have defined a much larger bargaining unit although the parties agreed to this. It will likely be a mail ballot which Amazon opposes which could help the union. 
Lastly, Amazon owns other businesses such as Whole Foods that may vote by the deadline.
